IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: To inspire youth to become science and technology leaders and innovators.
IRS990.MissionDesc: See Mission statement on Schedule O, pg. 159.The mission of FIRST is to inspire young people to be science and technology leaders and innovators, by engaging them in exciting mentor-based programs that build science, engineering, and technology skills, that inspire innovation, and that foster well-rounded life capabilities including self-confidence, communication, and leadership.
IRS990.Desc: FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) directly served approximately 83,700 youths on 3,347 teams. Working with mentors, each team builds a robot starting with a kit of parts, designing it to meet this year's game challenge "CHARGED UP." Each team participated in one or more 2 to 3-day events at 176 locations, competing for awards for game scores, safety practices, teamwork, and other qualitative achievements, stressing the FIRST ethos of Coopertition and Gracious Professionalism. Award-winning teams participated in the annual international FIRST Championship event in Houston, TX. The FRC Program provided students with the experience of applying engineering and technology to achieve a specific challenge under a time constraint. (Narrative continued on Schedule O, pg. 159).This experience developed students' technical skills, teamwork, and the ability to deal with the satisfactions and disappointments of a real engineering project. Participation in FIRST Robotics Competition has inspired many students to go on to college and careers in fields related to STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math). Many coaches and mentors work in these fields and help the students develop bonds within their communities and connections to the workforce development pipeline. Students and alumni of the program gain access to education and career discovery opportunities, connections to exclusive scholarships and employers, and a place in the FIRST community for life.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: FIRST LEGO League (FLL), for which there are three divisions, Discover, Explore and Challenge, reached approximately 497,532 youths aged 4-16, in 53,700 teams in 92 countries. This year's challenge was called "SUPERPOWERED." Participants explored where energy comes from and how it is distributed, stored, and used, and then put their superpowered creativity to work to innovate for a better energy future. Discover and Explore students built a LEGO model based on their energy journey and tracked what they learned in an Engineering Notebook. Explore teams used code to bring their model to life. Challenge teams developed new, innovative ways to rethink and improve how energy is generated and used. (Narrative continued on Schedule O, pg. 159).They also built and programmed an autonomous LEGO robot to solve energy-themed missions in the SUPERPOWERED Robot Game. In addition to participating in local events, teams from around the world met in Houston, TX in April 2023 as part of the FIRST Championship competition and celebration. Participation in Discover, Explore and Challenge has engaged students in a comprehensive experience developing confidence in their ability to address real world issues facing their communities, builds their STEM literacy and social-emotional learning, and exposes them to STEM careers. By progressing through each division and on to high-school level FIRST programs, students gain a full suite of technical skills and ongoing encouragement, making it more likely that they will pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and math.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: FIRST Tech Challenge (FTC) served approximately 87,500 youths from ages 12-18 on 6,832 teams. Like FIRST Robotics Competition, FIRST Tech Challenge teams design and build a robot to compete on a themed playing field but using a smaller robot kit and game challenge field. In this year's game, "POWER PLAY," each team built a robot and participated in local events. This program provides an experience for a broad audience of educators and students at a low cost. The experience simulates the excitement as well as the pressure of a real-life engineering project, developing not only the students' technical know-how, but also leadership, cooperation, ability to plan, patience, and teamwork. (Narrative continued on Schedule O, pg. 160).FIRST Tech Challenge enriches the participating students' ability to deal with the satisfactions and disappointments of a real engineering project. The experience expands students' interest and skills in STEM and inspires many to go on to higher education and careers in those fields. Students and alumni of the program gain access to education and career discovery opportunities, connections to exclusive scholarships and employers, and a place in the FIRST community for life.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: FIRST engaged one government affair consultant who communicated with federal and state government agencies for the purposes of promoting awareness of, and funding for, FIRST programs. This consultant was paid a total of $215,620 in tax year 2022 for services provided and reimbursement of expenses.

Reconciliation of Revenue per Audited Financial Statements (AFS): Total revenues and other support per AFS $86,020,663 Change in temporarily restricted net assets per AFS 2,128,666 Form 990, Schedule D, Part XI, Line 1 $88,149,329 Less: Donated services and use of facilities* (1,165,208) Less: Unrealized gain on investments (2,442) Total revenues per IRS Form 990 $86,981,679 *Donated services include: venue services, legal fees, and freight (Schedule D detailed reconcilations between Audited Financial Statements and Form 990 continued on next page)

In reference to Form 990, Part I, line 19 and Schedule D, Part XI, line 1 less Part XII, line 1: Excess revenue over expenses: Total revenue includes significant contributions by grantors to future years. The audited statements report operating income as follows: Total operating revenues and other support $86,020,663 Less: Total operating expenses (81,043,563) Operating Surplus $ 4,977,100 Change in temporarily restricted net assets 2,128,666 Less: Unrealized gain on investments (2,442) Change in net assets (Page 1, line 19) $7,103,324 Many unaffiliated organizations operate FIRST programs locally, including FIRST LEGO League and FIRST Tech Challenge tournaments, and certain FIRST Robotic Competition events. Revenues and expenses associated with those events are not included in FIRST's financial results.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: FIRST makes a limited number of grants to organizations outside of the United States primarily originating from restricted contributions for teams, tournament partners, and entities hosting FIRST program events. Grants are made exclusively for the purpose of allowing teams of students to participate in FIRST programs and are restricted to specific uses including the purchase of robotic kit parts, registration fees, team travel and event expenses. FIRST monitors the use of grant funds by often observing the actual funded event and by requiring annual grant reports to be submitted by the grantee summarizing the use of funds. Grants are made on condition that the recipient provide receipts, if requested, to substantiate that funds were used for the purposes intended by the grants.
Grants and event costs are reported at the amount expended. Non-cash assistance, primarily team fees, is reported at fair market value.

GrantsOtherAsstToIndivInUSGrp.GrantTypeTxt: Bart Kamen and Woodie Flowers Memorial Scholarships

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: FIRST makes grants to U.S. teams, tournament partners, schools, teachers, coaches, and entities hosting program events. Grants are primarily paid to educational institutions who administer disbursement of the funds. Grants ordinarily originate from donors who restrict the use of their contributions to cover teams' expenses based on varying criteria such as need, location, and underserved status. Funds granted are restricted to registration fees, team travel, event expenses, and other essentials. FIRST monitors the use of these funds by often observing the events and confirming through its registration system that all teams receiving grants are participating. Grants are made on condition that the recipient provide receipts, if requested, to substantiate that the funds were used for the intended purposes.

The Talent and Compensation Committee may grant discretionary performance incentives which, if granted, are determined after the fiscal year-end based on an individual employee's efforts and the overall FIRST financial outlook. Before receiving an incentive award, each Officer or Director's base compensation is reviewed, relative to the Talent and Compensation Committee's recommended parameters. Incentive compensation was paid in fiscal year 2023 (accrued in fiscal year 2022) to members of the leadership team. In May 2022 and December 2022 all FIRST employees, except for the CEO, were granted fiscal year bonuses and holiday gifts (bonuses), respectfully; these are reported on page 2, column B(ii).
Deferred compensation is the contribution made by FIRST to the employee's 401(k) account.

Non-taxable benefits are comprised of health, vision care, dental insurance premiums, and, if applicable, flexible spending accounts for health and dependent care. Some of the employees listed made contributions either towards health, vision care, and dental insurance; some did so for all of these. Some of the employees listed made contributions to a flexible spending account.

BusTrInvolveInterestedPrsnGrp.RelationshipDescriptionTxt: Family member of Ronald Falcone, Chief Sourcing Officer

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The kit of parts and on-line resources provided to each FRC and FLL team included components having significant value donated by many suppliers. To the extent fair market value can be determined, it is reported as revenue in the fiscal year. In addition, FIRST received a multitude of in-kind contributions of services essential to carrying out its events and programs. Support services have also been donated including building maintenance, marketing, distribution, information technology, engineering, and administrative services. The number and value of these in-kind contributions cannot be determined but were a substantial part of the resources necessary to deliver FIRST's program services during the year.

FIRST does not use third parties or related organizations to solicit, process, or sell non-cash donations, except for the sale of donations of publicly traded securities. These are sold through a third-party broker not related to FIRST.

The FIRST Scholarship Program attracted nearly 200 colleges, universities, businesses, and professional associations. These organizations made available over $90 million in college scholarships to FIRST program participants and alumni. FIRST provided guidance to high school students encouraging them to apply. Awards ranged from $500 to full tuition. The costs of the FIRST Scholarship Program are included on Form 990, Part III. The FIRST Volunteer Program provided support to teams, coaches and our regional staff around the world by recruiting, screening and training volunteers who are needed for all FIRST programs. An estimated 21,126,000 volunteer hours, including those of federally funded VISTA workers, provided much of the efforts behind FIRST's programs. The costs of the FIRST Volunteer Program are included on Form 990, Part III. For more information visit https://www.firstinspires.org/annual-report

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Dean Kamen and Robert M. Tuttle are employed by DEKA Research & Development Corp. (DEKA) serving as President and Executive Vice President, respectively, and collectively own more than a 35% interest in the corporation. Dean Kamen and Robert M. Tuttle are partners or members in several real estate partnerships/LLCs in which they collectively own more than a 35% interest.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Form 990 was reviewed in depth by the Audit Committee, the Board Treasurer, and the Vice President of FIRST with the outside CPA who prepared the return. After approval by the FIRST Audit Committee, a complete copy of the return was provided, via mail or email, to each FIRST Board Member. The return was then filed with the IRS. This year, the review took place on November 8, 2023.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The FIRST Conflict of Interest Policy requires every Director and Officer to disclose any known or potential conflict of interest to the Co-Chairs of the Board prior to any action, decision, or vote occurring connected with the potential conflict. The Co-Chairs of the Board, in consultation with the Audit Committee will determine if a conflict exists. The Director or Officer having the potential conflict is not permitted to participate when the determination is made or when a decision or vote is taken where a conflict of interest may exist. Annually, every Board Member and Officer is required to read and sign the policy and disclose any conflicts of interest, or attest to the fact that there are none, in writing. The signed annual statements and disclosures are sent to the independent auditors who report the results to the FIRST Audit Committee, the CPA preparing the Form 990, and the FIRST Treasurer.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Compensation of officers and certain directors is approved by the Talent and Compensation Committee of the BOD. Annual review performance evaluations, including measurement of the achievement of pre-established performance objectives, are the primary basis of determining every senior manager's raise/base salary. Compensation survey information is also considered in such determination. Changes in the compensation level, raise level, and bonus award for the CEO is recommended by the Talent and Compensation Committee to the Steering Committee for its approval. Performance against pre-established objectives, various qualitative assessments, and comparison to total compensation of CEOs of like organizations are all considered.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The audited financial statements are available through the FIRST website (www.firstinspires.org). The Articles of Incorporation, By-Laws, and Conflict of Interest Policy are made available to the public upon request.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part X, Line 10: Land, Buildings, and Equipment
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Section 1.263(a)-3(n) Election: For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology (FIRST) 200 Bedford Street Manchester, NH 03101-1132 EIN: 22-2990908 For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology (FIRST) is electing to capitalize repair and maintenance costs under Regulation Section 1.263(a)-3(n).
